thread.title: Finding fault with ‘San Andreas’
thread.title_full: Finding fault with ‘San Andreas’ - San Antonio Express-News

author: mysanantonio.com
title: Finding fault with ‘San Andreas’
text:
Photo: Warner Bros. Pictures Image 1 of / 4 4 Dwayne Johnson, left, rescues Carla Gugino from a pile of rubble that used to be Los Angeles in “San Andreas.”
Photo: Warner Bros. Pictures Dwayne Johnson, left, rescues Carla Gugino from a pile of rubble... Image 2 of 4 Amy Poehler is Joy in “Inside Out.”
Photo: Pixar Amy Poehler is Joy in “Inside Out.” Image 3 of 4 Keanu Reeves will have a hard time explaining this to his wife in “Knock Knock.”
Photo: Lionsgate Premiere Keanu Reeves will have a hard time explaining this to his wife in... Image 4 of 4 The future of the planet is in the hands of a couple of maintenance guys in “Air.”
Photo: Vertical Entertainment The future of the planet is in the hands of a couple of maintenance... Finding fault with ‘San Andreas’ 1 / 4 Back to Gallery Whether you stream, buy or rent, here’s a look at what’s new this week in home video. Movies are available on streaming sites such as iTunes, Amazon and Vudu unless otherwise noted.
Rent it now
“San Andreas”: State-of-the-art visual effects raise the discomfort level in what is otherwise an old-school Hollywood disaster movie. A series of massive earthquakes turn two great cities, Los Angeles and San Francisco, into rubble, with a couple of scenes mimicking iconic 9-11 imagery. But hope is not lost as long as an uncommonly attractive groups of survivors, including Dwayne Johnson and Alexandra Daddario , stay alive and photogenic.
Also: “Dope,” “The Gallows,” “Tomorrowland”
Buy it now
“Inside Out”: Pixar returns to form with this bittersweet, unclassifiable family film. Most of the movie’s action takes place inside the head of ’tween girl Riley, where her emotions — Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust — work overtime to cope with her family’s move to San Francisco. “As funny … as it is profound,” according to the Wall Street Journal .
Also: “Max,” “Pixels”
Still in theaters
“Knock Knock”: Director Eli Roth , whose cannibal flick “Green Inferno” opened a couple of weeks ago, turns down the gore in this, um, cautionary thriller. Keanu Reeves is a husband and father at home alone for the weekend. His decision to let two young women — “You don’t look that dangerous” — into his house to use the phone will turn out to be a poor one.
In focus
“Air”: When a global war makes the environment toxic, the United States puts its best and brightest into cold storage until the weather clears. A pair of maintenance men, “The Walking Dead’s” Norman Reedus and Djimon Hounson , are automatically awakened for a couple of hours every six months to check on things. When stuff starts malfunctioning on their current shift, a run to Home Depot is not an option.
